Checkpoint Logbook

You can use this component to log the arrivals, departures, solution etc. in multi–level puzzlehunt games. All the contents of the logbook are saved between sessions and it is also possible to export the data for an independent storage or post–processing in an external application.

Basic usage

When approaching a new checkpoint, or entering a new level of a puzzlehunt, click Add checkpoint. This opens a dialog with pre–filled arrival time and a checkpoint name, defaulting to \"Checkpoint\" and a ordinal number. Of course, the pre–filled fields can be edited just like any other ones.

When a puzzle is finished, you can record the time of departure clicking the last added item in the checkpoint list. A slightly different dialog appears, now allowing to record the solution of the puzzle and optional comments along with the departure time.

A previously closed checkpoint can also be revisited to review or change any piece of data associated with it. The full dialog comprises both the arrival– and departure–related fields together. NB that it is also possible to reveal the full version of the dialog at arrival using the Unfold button.

Export

For the purpose of storage or post–processing, the records can be exported in CSV (comma–separated values) format using the Export tab. The format used in the export is recognized by all major spreadsheet editors. You can filter the entries to appear in the exported file.

The file is exported in a folder called \"Puzzlehunt Assistant\" on the default storage device of your system; for convenience, the name of the newly created file appears for a second. The app also provides an interface to open the file in some editors installed on your device right after the export. However, the exported file is stored in the \"Puzzlehunt Assistant\" in either case.

Preferences

In the component settings, you can enable or disable the automatic numbering of checkpoints as \"Checkpoint 1, 2, …\". If the automatic numbering is disabled, newly opened checkpoints will have no pre–filled name. Even if it is enabled, the pre–filled name can be edited, e.g., to reflect irregularities in the numbering like \"1A\", \"1B\". When determining the name for a new checkpoint, the app will look for a first empty slot following the prescribed pattern.

Tips and tricks

If you fill in Specification or Remark in the checkpoint details, a \"…\" sign will appear next to it in the main list. This is a quick indication that there is further information available which is not readily visible in the overview.
